BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs represent the main danger. Gliding snow requires caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh wind slabs are prone to triggering in all aspects. Caution is to be exercised in particular above approximately 2200 m, as well as in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. Avalanches can be released easily and reach medium size. The prevalence of avalanche prone locations and likelihood of triggering will increase with altitude. Shooting cracks when stepping on the snowpack can indicate the danger.

There is a danger of gliding avalanches and moist snow slides. This applies on steep slopes below approximately 2400 m.

Weak layers in the old snowpack can be released especially by large additional loads in particular at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack, when entering gullies and bowls for example. This applies on very steep slopes above approximately 2200 m. Avalanches can reach large size in isolated cases.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Over a wide area 10 to 20 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen above approximately 1000 m. The wind will be strong in some cases, in particular in the east on the Main Alpine Ridge. As a consequence of new snow and wind from northwesterly directions, sometimes large wind slabs formed. More recent wind slabs are lying on soft layers in all aspects at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions. Faceted weak layers exist in the centre of the snowpack in particular above approximately 2200 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: As a consequence of rising temperatures the snowpack will settle during the next few days. Gradual decrease in danger of gliding avalanches as a consequence of the ceasing of precipitation.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The soft wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence in particular on near-ridge shady slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The new snow and wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence especially on north to northeast to northwest facing aspects. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular in north to northeast to northwest facing aspects and on wind-loaded slopes. Whumpfing sounds and the formation of shooting cracks when stepping on the snowpack serve as an alarm indicating the danger.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The snowpack remains unfavourable in particular on steep shady slopes. Backcountry touring calls for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and a moderate to strong wind from variable directions, sometimes large wind slabs formed above approximately 2300 m.
Weak layers exist in the top section of the snowpack at intermediate and high altitudes.
Avalanches can be released, even by small loads in isolated cases. This applies in particular on very steep slopes, and adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. At elevated altitudes the avalanche prone locations are more widespread.
Meticulous route selection is recommended.
At elevated altitudes more medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large dry avalanches are possible as a consequence of new snow and wind.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area there is more snow than usual, in particular above approximately 2200 m.
40 to 70 cm of snow has fallen since Monday above approximately 2500 m.
The rain gave rise to rapid and thorough wetting of the snowpack over a wide area below approximately 2400 m. And a rapid settlement of the snowpack below about 2200 m
As a consequence of falling temperatures a crust formed on the surface.
Towards its surface, the snowpack is weak in some cases.
Towards its base, the snowpack is largely stable.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment:
The danger will decrease gradually.
Continuous warming: These conditions will foster a gradual change towards better conditions in particular at low and intermediate altitudes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: As a consequence of the strong northerly wind the prevalence of the avalanche prone locations will increase during the night.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Until Saturday the wind will be strong in the vicinity of peaks. As a consequence of a gathering strong wind, further wind slabs will form. The wind slabs will form in particular above the tree line.
The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on wind-loaded slopes of all aspects above approximately 2300 m and at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack. The wind slabs can be released easily by a single winter sport participant.
At elevated altitudes more medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large dry avalanches are possible as a consequence of new snow and wind.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: 40 to 60 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, fell in the last five days above approximately 2300 m. The sleet gave rise to rapid settling of the snowpack below approximately 2200 m. As a consequence of falling temperatures a crust formed on the surface. Fresh wind slabs are bonding only slowly with the old snowpack in particular on steep shady slopes above approximately 2400 m. Snow depths vary greatly at intermediate and high altitudes, depending on the infuence of the wind.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The fresh wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Until Saturday the wind will be strong to storm force at times over a wide area. The wind will transport the new snow and, in some cases, old snow as well. As a consequence of a gathering strong wind from northwesterly directions, large surface-area wind slabs will form especially adjacent to ridgelines as well as above the tree line. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on wind-loaded slopes of all aspects above approximately 2000 m and at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack. The wind slabs can be released easily, even by a single winter sport participant, above the tree line.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Towards its base, the snowpack is faceted. This applies in particular on steep shady slopes above approximately 2000 m.
The sometimes storm force wind will transport the new snow significantly. In some regions up to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Wednesday above approximately 2000 m. The sleet gave rise to moistening of the snowpack below approximately 2000 m. Snow depths vary greatly at intermediate and high altitudes, depending on the infuence of the wind.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The wind will be strong to storm force at times over a wide area. In particular adjacent to ridgelines the wind slabs will increase in size additionally. On wind-loaded slopes a considerable avalanche danger will prevail.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs are to be evaluated with care and prudence.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The northwesterly wind will transport the loosely bonded old snow. The various wind slabs are to be evaluated with care and prudence in all aspects above approximately 2000 m. In some cases avalanches are medium-sized and can be released even by a single winter sport participant. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.
Weak layers in the old snowpack can be released in some places even by individual winter sport participants especially at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack, when entering gullies and bowls for example. This applies in particular on very steep northwest, north and northeast facing slopes in particular above approximately 2400 m. These avalanche prone locations are rather rare and are difficult to recognise.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
As a consequence of new snow and a moderate to strong northerly wind, further wind slabs will form on Thursday in all aspects. Wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on shady slopes at elevated altitudes. The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are mostly easy to recognise but can be released easily especially at their margins.
Faceted weak layers exist in the centre of the snowpack in particular above approximately 2400 m. Weak layers in the old snowpack are difficult to recognise.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: On Saturday the wind will be strong at times in some regions. In the late morning further wind slabs will form in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.

BulletinMeasurements.highlights: Currently there are quite favourable conditions generally. The old snowpack remains unfavourable in particular on very steep shady slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs can be released in some cases in particular on very steep shady slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The avalanche prone locations for dry avalanches are to be found in particular in the vicinity of peaks and on very steep shady slopes above approximately 2500 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The older wind slabs are easy for the trained eye to recognise and can only be released in isolated cases.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs and weakly bonded old snow require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh and older wind slabs are prone to triggering above approximately 2200 m. Mostly avalanches are medium-sized and can be released even by a single winter sport participant. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. In the regions neighbouring those that are subject to danger level 3 (considerable) the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent.

Weak layers in the old snowpack can be released in very isolated cases in particular at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack, when entering gullies and bowls for example. This applies on very steep shady slopes above approximately 2400 m, especially in the north. Avalanches can reach medium size.

On steep slopes mostly small gliding avalanches are possible below approximately 2000 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
As a consequence of a strong to storm force northwesterly wind, wind slabs will form. These are lying on soft layers in all aspects at elevated altitudes.
Faceted weak layers exist in the centre of the snowpack in particular above approximately 2400 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The avalanche danger will persist. The weather conditions will foster a gradual settling of the snow drift accumulations.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs require caution, especially along the border with France.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh snow and the mostly small wind slabs can still be released in some cases especially on very steep shady slopes above approximately 2700 m. The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are to be avoided in particular in very steep terrain.
In some places new snow is lying on an icy crust. Restraint should be exercised because avalanches can sweep people along and give rise to falls.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: In all altitude zones less snow than usual is lying. Below approximately 2200 m from a snow sport perspective, in most cases insufficient snow is lying. Snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. Towards its base, the snowpack is moist. The sleet gave rise to rapid settling of the snowpack below approximately 2500 m. As a consequence of falling temperatures a crust will form on the surface.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and a moderate to strong wind from westerly directions, sometimes deep wind slabs formed above approximately 2400 m.
Weak layers exist in the top section of the snowpack at intermediate and high altitudes.
Avalanches can be released, even by small loads in isolated cases. This applies in particular on very steep slopes, and adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.
At high altitudes and in high Alpine regions the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent.

At elevated altitudes more small and medium-sized dry avalanches are possible as a consequence of new snow and wind.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
20 to 40 cm of snow has fallen since Monday above approximately 2500 m.
The rain gave rise to rapid and thorough wetting of the snowpack over a wide area below approximately 2400 m. And a rapid settlement of the snowpack below about 2200 m
As a consequence of falling temperatures a crust formed on the surface.
Towards its surface, the snowpack is weak in some cases.
Towards its base, the snowpack is largely stable.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment:
The danger will decrease gradually.
Continuous warming: These conditions will foster a gradual change towards better conditions in particular at low and intermediate altitudes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs of the last few days represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of a strong wind from westerly directions, wind slabs formed at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions. The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs can be released even by a single winter sport participant in particular on very steep north, east and southeast facing slopes. In particular in high Alpine regions these avalanche prone locations are more prevalent. Gradual decrease in danger of moist and wet avalanches as the temperature drops.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: 10 to 20 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Monday above approximately 2300 m. The sleet gave rise to moistening of the snowpack below approximately 2500 m. As a consequence of falling temperatures a crust will form on the surface. The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are bonding only slowly with the old snowpack in particular on steep shady slopes above approximately 2400 m. Snow depths vary greatly at intermediate and high altitudes, depending on the infuence of the wind.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The old wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of a strong wind from northwesterly directions, mostly small wind slabs will form especially adjacent to ridgelines as well as above the tree line. The fresh wind slabs are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.

The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are to be assessed with care and prudence. On Friday the wind slabs will increase in size additionally. Mostly avalanches are small but can be released easily even by a single winter sport participant. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Snow depths vary greatly above the tree line, depending on the infuence of the wind. As a consequence of the strong northwesterly wind, the snow drift accumulations will increase in size. In some cases the various wind slabs have bonded poorly with the old snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: On Saturday the wind will be strong at times in some regions. In the late morning further wind slabs will form in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The fresh wind slabs are to be assessed with care and prudence. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. Mostly avalanches are small.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The wind slabs will form in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls and at elevated altitudes. Snow depths vary greatly above the tree line, depending on the infuence of the wind.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The snowpack will be well bonded at low altitude.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: In steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the icy crust.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The old snowpack is well consolidated and its surface has a strong melt-freeze crust.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: From a snow sport perspective, in most cases insufficient snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: In some places new snow is lying on an icy crust. Even in moderately steep terrain there is a danger of falling here.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: In all altitude zones hardly any snow is lying.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Thus far only isolated small avalanches are possible. The avalanche prone locations are to be found especially in gullies and bowls above approximately 1600 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The old snowpack remains subject to considerable local variations in high Alpine regions. A little new snow above approximately 1200 m. As a consequence of a moderate to strong northeasterly wind, small wind slabs will form adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Thus far only isolated small avalanches are possible. The avalanche prone locations are to be found especially in gullies and bowls above approximately 1500 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: A little new snow above approximately 1200 m. As a consequence of a moderate to strong northeasterly wind, small wind slabs will form adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.
